title: Is it Time to Get Rid of the QR Code Menu? A Debate
sub_head: We asked diners and industry experts to face off on whether virtual versions of the dining-out staple should be here to stay
body:
For the recurring series, That’s Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments—one in favor and the other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.
WHEN FOOD WRITER Allyson Reedy ventured into her first restaurant after lockdown was lifted in June 2020, the Broomfield, Colo., resident found a QR code–one of those graphics that look like postage-stamp-sized crossword puzzles–taped to the table in lieu of a menu. Like many eateries, Tangerine, a brunch spot in nearby Lafayette, switched to QR menus to help patrons keep their germs to themselves in the pandemic era. When a smartphone’s camera is aimed at a restaurant’s code, a menu pops up in the phone’s browser. Half of all full-service restaurants have switched over since March 2020, according to a survey by the National Restaurant Association.
